body: I found non trivial task to write test case to verify this change. Mocking of detectClassPathResourcesToStage from DataflowRunner class which is static method is not possible with Mockito, so I am looking for workaround.

Review status: 13 of 22 files reviewed at latest revision, 9 unresolved discussions. --- *[a discussion](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555#-Kp1BnmeU5aYp435knSC:-KpGYG7ArVgTy9TWNjex:brshb6k) (no related file):*
Previously, unsleepy22 (Cody) wrote…
Ben, Thanks for your comments. I'm ok to extend the discussion further before pulling this commit. So I'll reply on my proposal doc.
It may also be helpful to have a quick discussion on slack to iterate on what exactly the proposal is, and then update the list. Specifically, it seems like one possible path forward is to move towards a model where all Beam metrics delegate directly to some underlying metrics implementation and then runner never gets involved. Such a model would lose the ability to support committed metrics (we would need to make that decision consciously) but would then simplify the metrics implementations by allowing allowing the SDK to connect metrics to a metrics reporter, and then it is just a matter of implementing a Dropwizard metrics reporter. This would still mean that the Dropwizard library is only a dependency of the Dropwizard metrics reporter, not the base metrics interfaces. --- *[runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterCell.java, line 38 at r4](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555#-Kp1AGjycjkaup_Fr4lL:-KpGXh_5IPoTAmf1e0Fn:bvshfbz) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/aa9bff62c8b88cc8c6a36ec224b799d7217dbb4d/runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterCell.java#L38)):*
Previously, unsleepy22 (Cody) wrote…
It's ok for runners to implement meters without using a dropwizard Meter because my implementation only passes the Meter.count() to runners and based on the count, the runners are free to implement their own meters.
The meter count isn't enough to determine the rate without knowing at what points in time those events occurred. This makes it impossible for runners to implement their own meters. --- *[runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterData.java, line 49 at r4](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555#-Kp1Adm0vIK3FzCRiXe0:-KpGY7H9gXTDr74KvTmc:b5tvscc) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/aa9bff62c8b88cc8c6a36ec224b799d7217dbb4d/runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterData.java#L49)):*
Previously, unsleepy22 (Cody) wrote…
This is a point we need to consider: In a distributed application, is the sum of `mean` rates referable? Or can we calculate an accurate sum of mean rates? Especially for meters with different start times. I think m1,m5,m15 are more referable numbers. Even so, I still think your example is reasonable acceptable because the mean rate of each meter depicts the average rate calculated so far, i.e, an static value at 10:00, it makes sense to sum them together to get a total mean rate for all meters at that time. For the second problem, I'm not sure about the use case, could you take an example?
I don't the sum of mean rates is meaningful, but the "total rate" does make sense. This is why just adding the means isn't enough to compute the total rate. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555)*

This should probably be experimental for the time being.

@peihe, how do you see the importance of this flag vs. taking the time to get the right API for this type of configuration?

@tgroh

This also makes `IsBounded.UNBOUNDED` falsy, yes?

I imagine we'll never add other values, but it's worth noting that if we discover one then we'll have to go update a ton of code that depends on only `BOUNDED` being truthy.

Changes Unknown when pulling **5388c7d33b503b382c5f3d1c87ba0e338dab04c8 on XuMingmin:BEAM-2562** into ** on apache:DSL_SQL**.

Hmm, when I look at all the code, it looks like it already does the right thing. What you've added shouldn't really have an effect based on the `pruningPrefix` method. Can you add a test that fails before this change and succeeds afterwards? I know from the bug that we are loading classes that really shouldn't be loaded.
@jbonofre, thanks for the update!

Yes, this makes `IsBounded.UNBOUNDED` falsy too. We may want to just make this a boolean, but this is at least an improvement. 

@kennknowles if you have nay comments.

I like the readability of the enum. TBH I'd rather it was called `Boundedness` so noone would try to be boolean-ish about it :-)

But I don't feel a need to object or anything.
@takidau @jbonofre @kennknowles could you help to merge this PR?

R: @tgroh 
also CC @vikkyrk in case there's something funky going on here
retest this please

R: @tgroh 

There are a couple of hacks left in here:

 - Determining if something is a primitive via set difference "outputs minus inputs"
 - Hardcoding the fact that `ParDo` is the only transform where evaluating it correctly uses additional inputs (specifically, non-additional inputs). I think the right way to do this is probably to just put the main input in the payload and have the evaluator use that.
 - Hitting the DisplayData methods to get them to crash, to not regress validation, while leaving them out of the proto since it isn't on the critical path. Developing the actual translation in parallel.

But it still seems like a decent milestone to perhaps checkpoint where things are with the DirectRunner, depending on how egregious you find said hacks. Suggestions welcome.
Same feeling here, when I read the code,  will try to come up with a test case. I also think pruning the namespace might improve performance.

@tgroh @jkff I have a hunch that `TextIOTest` has been succeeding only because the pipeline is mutated before run. This PR first clones before run, causing stable unique name violations in `TextIOReadTest`.
Yup, hacking uniqueness works. Probably we should fix it. Filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-2632 as a starter ticket.
Thank you @JingsongLi @xumingming
